[[Image:MalczewskiJacek.1897.PortretStanislawaWitkiewicza.jpg|thumb|Stanisław Witkiewicz. Portrait by [[Jacek Malczewski]], 1897.]] '''Stanisław Witkiewicz''' (8 May 1851 in [[Pašiaušė]] – 5 September 1915 in [[Lovran]]) was a [[Poland|Polish]] [[painting|painter]], [[architecture|architect]], [[literature|writer]] and [[art theory|art theoretician]]. ==Life== Witkiewicz was born in the [[Lithuania]]n village of [[Pašiaušė]] ({{lang-pl|Poszawsze}}) in [[Samogitia]], at that time, in the [[partitions of Poland|partitioned]] [[Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth]] lands ruled by the [[Russian Empire]]. Witkiewicz studied in [[Saint Petersburg]], 1869–71, then in [[Munich]], 1872–75. He created the [[Zakopane Style of Architecture|Zakopane Style]] (''styl zakopiański'') (also known as Witkiewicz Style (''styl witkiewiczowski'')) in architecture.<ref>See picture in [[:pl:styl zakopiański|Polish article on ''styl zakopiański'']].</ref> He was strongly associated with [[Zakopane]] and promoted it in the art community. [[Image:Witkiewicz 3.jpg|thumb|left|150px|Witkiewicz with son ''[[Stanisław Ignacy Witkiewicz|Witkacy]]'', ca. 1893]] His son, [[Stanisław Ignacy Witkiewicz]], became a famous painter, playwright, novelist and philosopher, also known (from the [[conflation]] of his [[surname]] and [[middle name]]) by the pseudonym "Witkacy." The son's godmother was the internationally famous actress [[Helena Modjeska]] ([[Helena Modrzejewska]]), whom the elder Witkiewicz in 1876 had nearly accompanied to [[California]] in the [[United States]]. Witkiewicz had strong views against formal [[education]]: ''"school is completely at odds with the psychological make-up of human beings"''. He applied this principle in his son's upbringing and was disappointed when the 20-year-old Witkacy chose to enroll at the [[Jan Matejko Academy of Fine Arts|Academy of Fine Arts]] in [[Kraków]]. In 1908, suffering from [[tuberculosis]], the elder Witkiewicz left his family in Zakopane and relocated to Lovranno, a fashionable resort in what was then [[Austria-Hungary]], which today is in [[Croatia]].
